questions.text: A study is done to identify the normal bacterial flora of the mouth. One bacterial species that was found to colonize the mouth is a gram-positive coccus that grows in chains and is catalase-negative. When it is grown on blood agar, alpha-hemolysis is noted. Additionally, this bacterium was tested for optochin sensitivity and was optochin-resistant. Which of the following is an additional feature of this bacterium?
questions.solution:
Streptococcus viridans are Gram-positive streptococci that grow in chains and are part of the normal flora of the oropharynx. This group includes S. mutans, S. mitis, and S. sanguinis.

Like all streptococci, Streptococcus viridans are catalase-negative, which helps differentiate streptococci from staphylococci, as the latter are catalase-positive. When grown on blood agar, Streptococcus viridans mainly cause alpha-hemolysis, which is a green hemolysis due to the production of hydrogen peroxide. Alpha-hemolysis is also a feature of Streptococcus pneumoniae and therefore these two bacteria need to be distinguished.

The two main distinguishing features between S. viridans and S. pneumoniae is optochin sensitivity and bile solubility. While S. pneumoniae is optochin-sensitive and bile-soluble, Streptococcus viridans are optochin-resistant and bile-insoluble.  


Option Analysis

❌ It is encapsulated:
Incorrect: Streptococcus viridans species are not encapsulated. Streptococcus pneumoniae is a Gram-positive bacterium that has a capsule but is optochin-sensitive.  
❌ It produces IgA protease:
Incorrect: Streptococcus viridans species do not produce IgA protease. IgA protease is produced by Streptococcus pneumoniae which is optochin-sensitive.  
✅ It is bile-insoluble:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ It is urease positive:
Incorrect: Streptococcus viridans are not urease positive.  
❌ It grows in 6.5% NaCl  :
Incorrect: Streptococcus viridans do not grow in 6.5% NaCl.

questions.text: A bacterial strain is being studied in a laboratory. In one experiment, growth of the bacteria on MacConkey agar yields pink colonies. In the next experiment, the same bacteria is grown instead on EMB (eosin-methylene blue) agar, resulting in the growth of colonies with a green metallic sheen. Which of the following is the most likely bacterium described in the experiments?
questions.solution:
MacConkey agar is an indicator media that is used to differentiate lactose-fermenting bacteria from non- lactose-fermenting bacteria. Lactose-fermenting bacteria grow pink colonies on MacConkey agar, while non-lactose-fermenting bacterial colonies will remain colorless.

Lactose-fermenting bacteria include Escherichia coli, Klebsiella, Serratia, Enterobacter, and Citrobacter. All these will have pink colonies on MacConkey agar.  


E. coli can be differentiated from other lactose-fermenting bacteria by EMB agar. On EMB agar E. coli will grow as colonies with a green sheen. Other lactose-fermenting bacteria on EMB agar will grow as purple-black colonies.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Escherichia coli:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Klebsiella oxytoca:
Incorrect: Klebsiella is a lactose-fermenting bacterium and therefore will grow pink colonies on MacConkey agar. However, it produces purple-black colonies on EMB agar.  
❌ Serratia marcescens:
Incorrect: Serratia is a lactose-fermenting bacterium and therefore will grow pink colonies on MacConkey agar. However, it produces purple-black colonies on EMB agar.  
❌ Enterobacter cloacae:
Incorrect: Enterobacter is a lactose-fermenting bacterium and therefore will grow pink colonies on MacConkey agar. However, it produces purple-black colonies on EMB agar.  
❌ Citrobacter freundii  :
Incorrect: Citrobacter is a lactose-fermenting bacterium and therefore will grow pink colonies on MacConkey agar. However, it produces purple-black colonies on EMB agar.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for abrupt onset of blurry vision and drooping eyelids. The patient also had slurred speech. The patient returned yesterday from a hiking trip during which he drank water from a stream and ate homemade canned foods. Past medical history is unremarkable. Vital signs are within normal limits other than SpO2 of 88% on room air. Which of the following accurately characterizes the toxin most likely responsible for this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Induces production of high-titer antibodies by host the immune system
Partially derived from lipid A molecules
Found exclusively within the external cellular membrane of bacteria

questions.solution:
This patient’s symptoms of blurry vision, ptosis, and dysarthria are concerning for botulism. The hypoxia on room air is concerning for developing respiratory compromise. The patient likely developed botulism from eating improperly canned food. It is caused by exotoxins produced by the Gram-positive bacteria Clostridium botulinum. Differences between exotoxins and endotoxins are listed in the following table:  



Option Analysis

❌ Produced exclusively by Gram-negative bacteria:
Incorrect: This patient has symptoms of botulism. It is caused by exotoxins produced by the Gram-positive bacteria Clostridium botulinum.  
❌ Encoded by bacterial chromosomes:
Incorrect: This patient has symptoms of botulism, which is caused by exotoxins produced by Clostridium botulinum. Exotoxins are typically encoded by a plasmid as opposed to bacterial chromosomes.  
✅ Induces production of high-titer antibodies by host the immune system   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Partially derived from lipid A molecules  :
Incorrect: Endotoxins consist of a lipid A, O antigen, and core polysaccharide component. However, this patient’s symptoms of blurry vision, ptosis, and dysarthria are concerning for botulism. The condition is caused by exotoxins (not endotoxins) produced by the Gram-positive bacteria Clostridium botulinum.  
❌ Found exclusively within the external cellular membrane of bacteria:
Incorrect: Endotoxins are found within the external cellular membrane of Gram-negative bacteria. In contrast, this patient’s symptoms of blurry vision, ptosis, and dysarthria are concerning for botulism. The condition is caused by exotoxins (not endotoxins) produced by the Gram-positive bacteria Clostridium botulinum.

questions.text:
A researcher is culturing bacteria on blood agar. The agar plate is shown below. Which of the following pathogens was most likely isolated?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
Bacteria with hemolytic capabilities produce different patterns of hemolysis when plated on blood agar. The three patterns of hemolysis are alpha, beta, and gamma.  

Alpha-hemolysis is characterized by the reduction of red blood cell hemoglobin to methemoglobin, which leads to a green-brown discoloration of the medium. Examples of bacteria that cause alpha-hemolysis are Streptococcus pneumoniae and Streptococcus viridans.  

Beta-hemolysis is characterized by complete lysis of red blood cells, leading to a clear zone surrounding the bacterial colonies. Examples of bacteria that cause beta hemolysis include Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pyogenes, Streptococcus agalactiae, and Listeria monocytogenes.  

Finally, gamma-hemolysis is a somewhat self-contradictory term and describes the absence of hemolysis. In gamma-hemolysis, the culture medium does not change color.  

Option Analysis

❌ Staphylococcus aureus  :
Incorrect: The bacterial culture demonstrates colonies with greenish discoloration of the surrounding agar. This finding is consistent with alpha-hemolysis. In contrast, Staphylococcus aureus causes beta-hemolysis, which causes the surrounding agar to appear clear and pale.  
❌ Streptococcus pyogenes:
Incorrect: The bacterial culture demonstrates colonies with greenish discoloration of the surrounding agar. This finding is consistent with alpha-hemolysis. In contrast, Streptococcus pyogenes causes beta hemolysis, which causes the surrounding agar to appear clear and pale.  
❌ Pseudomonas aeruginosa  :
Incorrect: The bacterial culture demonstrates colonies with greenish discoloration of the surrounding agar (alpha hemolysis). Pseudomonas aeruginosa does not cause hemolysis on blood agar.  
❌ Escherichia coli  :
Incorrect: The bacterial culture demonstrates colonies with greenish discoloration of the surrounding agar (alpha hemolysis). Escherichia coli does not cause hemolysis on blood agar.  
✅ Streptococcus pneumoniae:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A scientist identifies a bacterium that appears red under the microscope after Gram-staining. Which of the following is most likely true regarding this organism?

choices.text: Contains a thick outer peptidoglycan cell wall
Capable of forming spores in response to adverse environmental conditions
Possesses an outer and inner cell membrane

questions.solution:
This scientist identified a Gram-negative organism, which appears red after Gram-staining. Features distinguishing Gram-negative and Gram-positive organisms include the following:  



Option Analysis

❌ Contains a thick outer peptidoglycan cell wall  :
Incorrect: Gram-positive bacteria contain a thick outer peptidoglycan cell wall. The thick cell wall traps crystal violet dye used in Gram-staining, thereby giving these organisms a purple color.  
❌ Capable of forming spores in response to adverse environmental conditions  :
Incorrect: The scientist identified a Gram-negative organism, as it appears red after Gram-staining. Gram-negative organisms are unable to form spores. In contrast, some Gram-positive bacteria are able to form spores.  
❌ Cytoplasmic membrane contains lipoteichoic acid:
Incorrect: Lipoteichoic acid is found in the cell walls of Gram-positive organisms and regulates autolytic wall enzymes. In contrast, this scientist identified a Gram-negative organism, which appears red after Gram-staining.
❌ Cannot undergo aerobic respiration  :
Incorrect: The ability to undergo aerobic respiration is not specific to Gram-positive or Gram-negative bacteria. Examples of aerobic Gram-negative bacteria include Haemophilus, Legionella, and Bordetella species.  
✅ Possesses an outer and inner cell membrane  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: One of the major causes of hospital-acquired infections are Staphylococcus aureus species that are resistant to methicillin, oxacillin, and cephalosporins. Which of the following best explains the mechanism by which these bacteria develop antibiotic resistance?

choices.text: Inactivation of the drugs by acetylation
Amino acid modification of D-Ala D-Ala to D-Ala D-Lac

questions.solution:
Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) is one of the most common causes of hospital-acquired infections. The pathogen can cause pneumonia, endocarditis, and sepsis. MRSA is resistant to many β-lactam, including methicillin, oxacillin, and cephalosporins.

The mechanism of resistance of MRSA to β-lactams is due to the mec gene, which leads to alterations in the structure of penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs). PBPs are proteins responsible for synthesizing the cell wall and are the target of β-lactam antibiotics. The presence of an altered PBP target site structure prevents most β-lactams from binding, thereby rendering them ineffective against MRSA. The mec gene can be transferred to other S. aureus strains by bacteriophages in a process known as transduction.

Option Analysis

❌ Production of drug efflux pumps:
Incorrect: Efflux pumps are a mechanism by which bacteria can develop resistance to tetracyclines and fluoroquinolones. However, MRSA resistance to β-lactams is due to alterations in the structure of penicillin-binding proteins.  
❌ Inactivation of the drugs by acetylation:
Incorrect: Aminoglycoside resistance is due to an enzyme called transferase, which inactivates the drug molecules by acetylation, phosphorylation, or adenylation. However, MRSA resistance to β-lactams is due to alterations in the structure of penicillin-binding proteins.  
❌ Production of β-lactamase enzyme:
Incorrect: Certain bacteria have resistance to β-lactams due to the production of β-lactamase enzymes, which cleave the β-lactam ring. However, MRSA resistance to β-lactams is due to altered penicillin-binding protein structure.  
❌ Amino acid modification of D-Ala D-Ala to D-Ala D-Lac:
Incorrect: D-Ala D-Ala is an amino acid that forms a portion of the cell wall precursors. Vancomycin binds D-Ala D-Ala and inhibits cell wall synthesis. Vancomycin resistance occurs via amino acid modification of D-Ala D-Ala to D-Ala D-Lac. However, MRSA develops resistance to β-lactams via a different mechanism of action.  
✅ Alteration of penicillin-binding protein structure:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with chest pain, fever, and shortness of breath. The symptoms developed one day ago. Several years ago the patient was involved in a motor vehicle accident which resulted in multiple rib fractures and splenic rupture. Current temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), blood pressure 142/87 mmHg, pulse 110/min, and respiratory rate 22/min. Physical examination shows decreased breath sounds in the left lower lobe. Chest radiograph shows a dense left lower lobe consolidation. Sputum analysis reveals an organism containing a polysaccharide capsule. Which of the following pathogens is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has chest pain, fever, shortness of breath, and decreased breath sounds in the left lower lobe. These findings are concerning for pneumonia which is supported by the chest radiograph. The isolated organism is found to have a polysaccharide capsule. Among the answer choices, Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms, especially since it is the most common organism causing community-acquired pneumonia.  

The bacterial capsule is a polysaccharide layer that lies outside of the cell. Examples of encapsulated bacteria include Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae type b, Neisseria meningitidis, Escherichia coli, Salmonella, and Klebsiella. The capsule acts as a shield that protects against phagocytosis and helps bacteria adhere to surfaces. The capsule is considered an important virulence factor since bacterial strains lacking the capsule are generally less virulent.  

Antibodies and complements can bind to the capsules of invading bacteria and target them for destruction by the spleen. Hence, individuals with asplenia are at higher risk of infections by encapsulated bacteria.  

The capsule can also be isolated, conjugated to a protein, and serve as a potent antigen used in vaccinations. Examples of vaccinations using conjugated capsules include the Haemophilus influenzae type b and pneumococcal (e.g. PCV13) vaccines.   

Option Analysis

❌ Escherichia coli  :
Incorrect: This patient likely has pneumonia. The patient’s history of asplenia puts him at increased risk of infection by encapsulated organisms. While E. coli is an encapsulated bacteria, it does not typically cause pneumonia.  
✅ Streptococcus pneumoniae:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Staphylococcus aureus  :
Incorrect: Staphylococcus aureus can cause pneumonia which is often cavitating. However, the organism lacks a capsule.  
❌ Neisseria meningitidis:
Incorrect: This patient likely has pneumonia. The patient’s history of asplenia puts him at increased risk of infection by encapsulated organisms. While N. meningitidis is an encapsulated bacteria, it does not typically cause pneumonia.  
❌ Mycobacterium tuberculosis  :
Incorrect: Mycobacterium tuberculosis is an acid-fast organism that can cause pulmonary infection. However, it classically causes cavitary lesions and/or diffuse pulmonary lesions, as opposed to a single lobar consolidation.

questions.text: A researcher is examining bacteria under a microscope. They notice that Staphylococcus aureus appears purple after undergoing Gram-staining. An abundance of which of the following molecules is most likely responsible for the purple color?
questions.solution:
Gram-staining is used as part of bacterial identification. The process involves first staining bacteria with a crystal violet stain followed by a counterstain (e.g., fuchsin). Bacteria with a thick peptidoglycan cell wall will retain the crystal violet dye and appear purple under microscopy. Hence, these organisms are termed Gram-positive. In contrast, bacteria with a thin peptidoglycan cell wall will turn red after the counterstain has been applied. These organisms are termed Gram-negative.  

Option Analysis

✅ Peptidoglycan:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Mycolic acid  :
Incorrect: Bacteria containing mycolic acids, such as Nocardia and Mycobacterium, will appear red after acid-fast staining. However, Staphylococcus aureus does not contain mycolic acid. Instead, the thick peptidoglycan cell wall gives Staphylococcus aureus a purple color after Gram-staining.  
❌ Lipoteichoic acid:
Incorrect: Bacteria with a thick peptidoglycan cell wall will retain crystal violet dye, which is used in Gram-staining. These organisms will appear purple after Gram-staining due to peptidoglycan, not due to lipoteichoic acid.  
❌ Glycogen:
Incorrect: Bacteria with a thick peptidoglycan cell wall will retain crystal violet dye, which is used in Gram-staining. As a result, these organisms will appear purple after Gram-staining. Glycogen is not responsible for retaining crystal violet dye.  
❌ Flagella:
Incorrect: Crystal violet dye is used as part of Gram-staining. The dye binds to the thick peptidoglycan cell wall of certain bacteria, thereby giving the cells a purple appearance. Flagella protrude from the cell and are not responsible for holding dye and making Gram-positive bacteria stain purple.

questions.text: A researcher is studying a bacterial strain. The bacteria are found to produce a thick-walled intracellular structure when exposed to harsh environmental conditions. This structure enables the bacteria to become dormant, thereby minimizing metabolism. Which of the following pathogens is this researcher most likely studying?
questions.solution:
Some Gram-positive bacteria are capable of forming endospores, which are thick-walled intracellular structures containing the bacteria’s DNA and ribosomes when exposed to harsh environmental conditions. Bacteria in the endospore stage have little metabolic activity and are highly resistant to heat and chemicals.  

Examples of spore-forming bacteria include members of the Bacillus species (e.g., Bacillus anthracis, Bacillus cereus) and Clostridium species (e.g., Clostridium botulinum, Clostridium difficile, Clostridium perfringens).  

Bacterial endospores are highly resistant to heat and chemicals. However, autoclaving (with bacteria exposed to steam over 121°C for at least 15 minutes), hydrogen peroxide, and iodine-based agents are capable of destroying spores.  

Option Analysis

❌ Pseudomonas aeruginosa  :
Incorrect: Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a Gram-negative bacteria that is incapable of producing endospores.  
❌ Bordetella pertussis  :
Incorrect: The bacterial strain identified by this researcher is capable of producing endospores when exposed to harsh environmental conditions. Bordetella pertussis is incapable of producing endospores.  
❌ Streptococcus pneumoniae:
Incorrect: The bacterial strain identified by this researcher is capable of producing endospores when exposed to harsh environmental conditions. Streptococcus pneumoniae is incapable of producing endospores.  
✅ Clostridium botulinum:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Neisseria meningitidis  :
Incorrect: Neisseria meningitidis is a Gram-negative bacteria. In contrast, only Gram-positive organisms are capable of producing endospores, which allow bacteria to become dormant when exposed to unfavorable environmental conditions.

questions.text: A researcher is studying bacterial genetics. Using electron microscopy, they notice that a pilum has formed between two adjacent bacteria. A circular piece of DNA is subsequently transferred from one bacterium to another. Which of the following processes did this researcher most likely observe?
questions.solution:
There are several processes that facilitate the transfer of genetic material between different bacteria. Examples of such processes can be found below:  



Option Analysis

❌ Transformation:
Incorrect: Transformation describes the process wherein bacteria bind and uptake short fragments of naked bacterial DNA (from lysed bacteria) from the environment.  
✅ Conjugation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Transduction:
Incorrect: Transduction is the process by which a virus transfers genetic material from one bacterium to another.  
❌ Transposition:
Incorrect: In bacteria, transposons are segments of DNA that can jump from chromosomal DNA to plasmid DNA (and vice versa). This process enables the permanent addition of genes to the bacterium’s genome as well as the creation of plasmids that can be transferred to other bacteria.  
❌ Ubiquitination:
Incorrect: Ubiquitination is the process wherein ubiquitin molecules are added to a protein, thereby marking the protein for destruction.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man is brought to the emergency department from a skilled nursing facility because of altered mental status and decreased oral intake. Symptoms began yesterday evening. Temperature is 38.4°C (101°F), blood pressure 92/51 mmHg, pulse 112/min, respiratory rate 20/min, and SpO2 95% on room air. On physical examination the patient appears lethargic, does not respond to commands, and withdraws extremities in response to pain. Blood cultures grow Escherichia coli. Which of the following best characterizes the bacterial toxin responsible for this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Inhibits release of acetylcholine into the neuromuscular junction
Released primarily during bacterial cell lysis
Secreted into surrounding environment via exocytosis

questions.solution:
This patient presents with altered mental status, hypotension, and fever in the setting of Escherichia coli bacteremia, making the diagnosis of sepsis. Endotoxins, which are released from lysed bacterial cells or via blebs detaching from the surface of living cells, are a common cause of sepsis.  

Endotoxins are found in the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria and consist of a core polysaccharide component, lipid A, and O antigen. In response to released endotoxins, the body increases the production of IL-1, IL-6, and TNF-α, which leads to fever, vasodilation, and vascular leakage. In rare cases, endotoxins can cause excessive overactivation of the coagulation cascade and trigger disseminated intravascular coagulation.  

Option Analysis

❌ Inhibits release of acetylcholine into the neuromuscular junction  :
Incorrect: The exotoxin produced by Clostridium botulinum inhibits acetylcholine release at the neuromuscular junction, thereby causing flaccid paralysis. In contrast, this patient has signs of sepsis from Escherichia coli. These symptoms are likely due to endotoxins released from bacterial cells upon lysis.  
✅ Released primarily during bacterial cell lysis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inactivates elongation factor 2:
Incorrect: The exotoxin produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae inhibits elongation factor 2. In contrast, this patient has signs of sepsis from Escherichia coli. These symptoms are likely due to endotoxins released from bacterial cells upon lysis.  
❌ Secreted into surrounding environment via exocytosis:
Incorrect: This patient has signs of sepsis from Escherichia coli. These symptoms are likely due to endotoxins released from bacterial cells upon lysis, as opposed to via exocytosis.  
❌ Suppressed production of interleukin-1  :
Incorrect: Endotoxins are released from bacterial cells upon lysis. Endotoxins stimulate (rather than suppress) the production of inflammatory cytokines such as IL-1, IL-6, and TNF-α.
